“I can’t tell you,” he said, anguish in his eyes. “You won’t understand. You’ll only suffer.” 

Sonia embraced him, tears streaming. “But aren’t you suffering too?”

He sighed. “I have a bad heart. I’m a coward. A mean wretch.” 

“Why did you come?” she asked, desperate for answers.

“I wanted to be a Napoleon,” he confessed. “That’s why I killed her.” 

“N-no,” Sonia whispered. “Only speak. I will understand.” 

He paused, lost in thought. “You’ll understand? We shall see.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov confesses to Sonia that his desire to become a great figure like Napoleon motivated his crime, revealing his inner turmoil and sense of guilt.
